chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: Whether you are brand new to creating and modifying medical terminology tools, MindComputing's Knowledge is an intuitive web application to use. This article will show you the fastest way to get the most value out of Knowledge by using key features, such as search, creating a new concept, and running the classifier but first we will describe the login process and the overall application layout.

section.title: Accessing Knowledge for the First Time
section.para: To access Knowledge Editor, you need a username and temporary password assigned to you by an administrator who has permissions to manage the application. You should receive login information and url in your e-mail.

Once you log in, you may see one of two screens:
Generic Welcome Screen
If the administrator has not assigned projects to your account, you can only edit your user profile, e-mail, and password. Contact your administrator for project assignment.
Project-specific Welcome Screen
If a project has been assigned to you, Knowledge Editor will load, providing you a view of the taxonomy and announcements panels.
Image of the Editor screen after login displays a taxonomy list, announcements, and assigned projects.

simplesect.title: What happens if I forget my username/login?
simplesect.para: There are links to request your username or a password reset on the login page of the application. Select the information you need and fill out the information to receive next steps.

simplesect.title: What are my account permissions?
simplesect.para: You can review your account permissions under Account Preferences. To access this page, select your username in the top navigation menu, then select "Account Preferences". The table will display the projects assigned to you and the permissions you have under each project.

section.para: The Knowledge application is organized into 2 areas: Editor and Manager. The manager is only available to administrators, so we will lay out the Editor functionalities in this article.

section.title: Knowledge Editor
section.para:
The Editor is an interactive application that allows you to search, view, edit, and create terminologies, reference sets, and search criteria. By default, it is divided into 2 sections: the task pane and the concept viewer pane. When you select a concept on the left task pane, its details can be viewed in the right details pane.
Figure of the Knowledge Editor layout as described above.
You can optionally open another concept viewer pane that will display on the far right side of the window. There are three ways to do so:
Right-click the concept you wish to review and select "open in new concept viewer".
Highlight the concept you want to see in a new viewer and press " keyboard shortcut tbd, e.g. ctrl+alt+n " to open a new concept viewer.
In the top navigation pane, select "Authoring", then "Launch Third View".

section.title: What can I do in the Editor?
section.para: The Editor has tasks divided under 2 interfaces: Authoring and Export Management. You can access either of these interfaces in the top navigation anytime you are logged into the Editor.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Figure of the Knowledge Editor navigation with the interfaces highlighted

section.para: The application indicates which area and interface you are working with on the upper left corner.

section.title: Authoring
section.para: The Authoring interface provides information on concepts and terminologies, lists reference sets, queries, mapsets, enables user to run the classifier, and allows user to search for items in the database. Depending on your account permissions, there is also the ability to edit many of the previously mentioned items.

section.title: Export Management
section.para: The Export Management interface is viewable by users who have Editing permissions. Tasks such as QA runs, content releases, metric reports, and conflict resolutions are done under this interface, but the Content Manager has permissions to create a release version in this area.

section.title: How do I find terminologies?
section.para: You can search for terminologies under the Authoring interface. On the left pane, there are options to find the concepts directly in its taxonomy tree or to search for keywords.

section.title: Taxonomy Tree
section.para: One of the ways to view terminologies or concepts is to locate the item in the taxonomy tree in the left pane. Simply select the terminology you want to view in its relationship tree. To expand a concept module, select the caret symbol on the left of the tree to expand its children terminologies.

section.title: Search
section.para: Terminologies can be searched by keywords under the Search tab in the left pane. After the keywords are entered, select the button "Search" to retrieve results. Knowledge supports Lucene search and FLWOR queries in this area as well, for more information select the info icon next to the search field.

section.title: Advanced Search
section.para: There are several ways to narrow down the search criteria under the "Advanced Search" and "SNOMED Filters" sections of the Search tab. Select the button "Search" to retrieve results after any search criteria changes. Selecting the "Reset" button will clear all fields in the Search tab. A figure of the available filter criteria is shown below.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Figure of the Search tab with additional filter criteria such as Status, Path, STAMP date range, Author, Modules, and Description type.

section.title: Saved Searches
section.para: Search criteria can be saved for later user under the Search tab. To do so, enter the search criteria and select the "Search" button. A results section should appear below the search fields along with options to save the search and to export the results to a CSV file. Select the "Save Search" link in order to name and save the search.

Saved searches are retrieved under the "saved searches" section of the search tab. This section is only visible if there are previously saved searches. Select the desired search from a dropdown list and press the "Search" button to pull results.

section.title: Viewing Terminologies/Concepts
section.para: Once a concept is selected, its details is displayed on one of the Concept Viewer panes. The pane lists the general concept information such as STAMP (define STAMP), its descriptions which include additional names it may be known by in other languages and dialects, and the axiom history which illustrates its taxonomy relationship. Details such as the inferred information or inactive items can be toggled on by selecting "Display options" in the upper right corner, and its refset relationships and history can be found in tabs within the same panel.

inlinemediaobject.alt: Figure of the Display Options modal from the concept viewer. Displays options such as "Show authors, language, modules, filter STAMP date," and more.

section.title: Using the Briefcase
section.para: A briefcase is where you can temporarily hold concepts so that you can review them later. For example, if you run the classifier and it identifies multiple duplicates, you may want to add them to your briefcase so that you can access the list of concepts quickly to compare. Or if you're reviewing the concept's associated members, the table may have an option to add them to your briefcase.

To add a terminology to your briefase from some lists such as classifier page, select the briefacse icon (not all tables have this feature). Simply click on the briefcase icon to add or remove it from your list. Your briefcase is viewable in the left pane navigation.

section.title: Selecting a Project Area
section.para: The name of the project area you are currently working on is indicated on the top left corner of the application. If you are assigned to multiple projects, you may switch to a different area by selecting "Projects" in the top navigation menu.
